Mean Functions API¶

These are the currently supported mean functions:

src.Core.means.meanConst(meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶
Constant mean function. The mean function is parameterized as:
m(x) = c
The hyperparameter is:
meanhyper = [ c ]
src.Core.means.meanLinear(meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶
Linear mean function. The mean function is parameterized as:
m(x) = sum_i ai * x_i
The hyperparameter is:
meanhyper = [ a_1 a_2 ... a_D ]
src.Core.means.meanMask(meanfunc, meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶

meanMask - compose a mean function as another mean function (meanfunc), but with only a subset of dimensions of x.

src.Core.means.meanOne(meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶

One mean function. The mean function does not have any parameters m(x) = 1

src.Core.means.meanPow(meanfunc, meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶
Compose a mean function as the power of another one
m(x) = m0(x) ** d

This function doesn’t actually compute very much on its own. it merely does some bookkeeping, and calls another mean function to do the actual work.

src.Core.means.meanProd(meanfunc, meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶

meanProd - compose a mean function as the product of other mean functions. This function doesn’t actually compute very much on its own, it merely does some bookkeeping, and calls other mean functions to do the actual work.

src.Core.means.meanScale(meanfunc, meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶

Compose a mean function as a scaled version of another one k(x^p,x^q) = sf2 * k0(x^p,x^q)

The hyperparameter is :
meanhyper = [ log(sf2) ]

This function doesn’t actually compute very much on its own. it merely does some bookkeeping, and calls another mean function to do the actual work.

src.Core.means.meanSum(meanfunc, meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶

covSum - compose a mean function as the sum of other mean functions. This function doesn’t actually compute very much on its own, it merely does some bookkeeping, and calls other mean functions to do the actual work.

src.Core.means.meanZero(meanhyper=None, x=None, der=None)¶
Zero mean function. The mean function does not have any parameters
m(x) = 1
